column2: It was on November 18th that the snow came.
column3: It was on november eighteenth that the snow came.

column2: In the morning we woke to window-ledges heaped white, and snowflakes falling so whirling thick that it was impossible to see ten feet ahead.
column3: In the morning we woke to window ledges heaped white, and snowflakes falling so whirling thick that it was impossible to see ten feet ahead.

column2: The mud was gone; in a twinkling the gloomy city became white, dazzling.
column3: The mud was gone; in a twinkling the gloomy city became white, dazzling.

column2: The _droshki_ with their padded coachmen turned into sleights, bounding along the uneven street at headlong speed, their drivers' beards stiff and frozen....

column2: In spite of Revolution, all Russia plunging dizzily into the unknown and terrible future, joy swept the city with the coming of the snow.

column2: Everybody was smiling; people ran into the streets, holding out their arms to the soft, falling flakes, laughing.

column2: The traditional peasant party was the Socialist Revolutionary party; of all the parties now supporting the Soviet Government, the Left Socialist Revolutionaries were the logical inheritors of peasant leadership--and the Left Socialist Revolutionaries, who were at the mercy of the organised city proletariat, desperately needed the backing of the peasants....

column2: The Peasants' Congress, fully supporting the Land decree of November 8th... approves of the Provisional Workers' and Peasants' Government of the Russian Republic, established by the second All-Russian Congress of Soviets of Workers' and Soldiers' Deputies.
column3: The Peasants' Congress, fully supporting the Land decree of november eighth... approves of the Provisional Workers' and Peasants' Government of the Russian Republic, established by the second All Russian Congress of Soviets of Workers' and Soldiers' Deputies.

column2: The Peasants' Congress... invites all peasants unanimously to sustain that law, and to apply it immediately themselves; and at the same time invites the peasants to appoint to posts and positions of responsibility only persons who have proved, not by words but by acts, their entire devotion to the interests of the exploited peasant-workers, their desire and their ability to defend these interests against all resistance on the part of the great land-owners, the capitalists, their partisans and accomplices....
column3: The Peasants' Congress... invites all peasants unanimously to sustain that law, and to apply it immediately themselves; and at the same time invites the peasants to appoint to posts and positions of responsibility only persons who have proved, not by words but by acts, their entire devotion to the interests of the exploited peasant workers, their desire and their ability to defend these interests against all resistance on the part of the great land owners, the capitalists, their partisans and accomplices....

column2: The Peasants' Congress, at the same time, expresses its conviction that the complete realisation of all the measures which make up the Land decree can only be successful through the triumph of the Workers' Social Revolution, which began November 7th, 1917; for only the Social Revolution can accomplish the definite transfer, without possibility of return, of the land to the peasant-workers, the confiscation of model farms and their surrender to the peasant communes, the confiscation of agricultural machinery belonging to the great land-owners, the safe-guarding of the interests of the agricultural workers by the complete abolition of wage-slavery, the regular and methodical distribution among all regions of Russia of the products of agriculture and industry, and the seizure of the banks (without which the possession of land by the whole people would be impossible, after the abolition of private property), and all sorts of assistance by the State to the workers....
column3: The Peasants' Congress, at the same time, expresses its conviction that the complete realisation of all the measures which make up the Land decree can only be successful through the triumph of the Workers' Social Revolution, which began november seventh nineteen seventeen; for only the Social Revolution can accomplish the definite transfer, without possibility of return, of the land to the peasant workers, the confiscation of model farms and their surrender to the peasant communes, the confiscation of agricultural machinery belonging to the great land owners, the safe guarding of the interests of the agricultural workers by the complete abolition of wage slavery, the regular and methodical distribution among all regions of Russia of the products of agriculture and industry, and the seizure of the banks (without which the possession of land by the whole people would be impossible, after the abolition of private property), and all sorts of assistance by the State to the workers....

column2: For these reasons the Peasants' Congress sustains entirely the Revolution of November 7th... as a social revolution, and expresses its unalterable will to put into operation, with whatever modifications are necessary, but without any hesitation, the social transformation of the Russian Republic.
column3: For these reasons the Peasants' Congress sustains entirely the Revolution of november seventh... as a social revolution, and expresses its unalterable will to put into operation, with whatever modifications are necessary, but without any hesitation, the social transformation of the Russian Republic.

column2: The indispensable conditions of the victory of the Social Revolution, which alone will secure the lasting success and the complete realisation of the Land decree, is the close union of the peasant-workers with the industrial working-class, with the proletariat of all advanced countries.
column3: The indispensable conditions of the victory of the Social Revolution, which alone will secure the lasting success and the complete realisation of the Land decree, is the close union of the peasant workers with the industrial working class, with the proletariat of all advanced countries.

column2: From now on, in the Russian Republic, all the organisation and administration of the State, from top to bottom, must rest on that union.
column3: From now on, in the Russian Republic, all the organisation and administration of the State, from top to bottom, must rest on that union.

column2: That union, crushing all attempts, direct or indirect, open or dissimulated, to return to the policy of conciliation with the bourgeoisie--conciliation, damned by experience, with the chiefs of bourgeois politics--can alone insure the victory of Socialism throughout the world....
column3: That union, crushing all attempts, direct or indirect, open or dissimulated, to return to the policy of conciliation with the bourgeoisie-conciliation, damned by experience, with the chiefs of bourgeois politics-can alone insure the victory of Socialism throughout the world....

column3: On the steps of Smolny about a hundred Workers' and Soldiers' Deputies were massed, with their banner, dark against the blaze of light streaming out between the arches.

column2: Like a wave they rushed down, clasping the peasants in their arms and kissing them; and the procession poured in through the great door and up the stairs, with a noise like thunder....
column3: Like a wave they rushed down, clasping the peasants in their arms and kissing them; and the procession poured in through the great door and up the stairs, with a noise like thunder....

column2: In the immense white meeting-room the _Tsay-ee-kah_ was waiting, with the whole Petrograd Soviet and a thousand spectators beside, with that solemnity which attends great conscious moments in history.
column3: In the immense white meeting room the underscore Tsay ee kah underscore was waiting, with the whole Petrograd Soviet and a thousand spectators beside, with that solemnity which attends great conscious moments in history.

column2: Zinoviev announced the agreement with the Peasants' Congress, to a shaking roar which rose and burst into storm as the sound of music blared down the corridor, and the head of the procession came in.
column3: Zinoviev announced the agreement with the Peasants' Congress, to a shaking roar which rose and burst into storm as the sound of music blared down the corridor, and the head of the procession came in.

column2: On the platform the presidium rose and made place for the Peasants' presidium, the two embracing; behind them the two banners were intertwined against the white wall, over the empty frame from which the Tsar's picture had been torn....
column3: On the platform the presidium rose and made place for the Peasants' presidium, the two embracing; behind them the two banners were intertwined against the white wall, over the empty frame from which the Tsar's picture had been torn....

column2: Then opened the "triumphal session." After a few words of welcome from Sverdlov, Maria Spiridonova, slight, pale, with spectacles and hair drawn flatly down, and the air of a New England school-teacher, took the tribune--the most loved and the most powerful woman in all Russia.
column3: Then opened the "triumphal session." After a few words of welcome from Sverdlov, Maria Spiridonova, slight, pale, with spectacles and hair drawn flatly down, and the air of a New England school teacher, took the tribune-the most loved and the most powerful woman in all Russia.

column2: Then Trotzky, full of fire: "I wish you welcome, comrades peasants! You come here not as guests, but as masters of this house, which holds the heart of the Russian Revolution.
column3: Then Trotzky, full of fire: "I wish you welcome, comrades peasants! You come here not as guests, but as masters of this house, which holds the heart of the Russian Revolution.

column2: The will of millions of workers is now concentrated in this hall....
column3: The will of millions of workers is now concentrated in this hall....

column2: There is now only one master of the Russian land: the union of the workers, soldiers and peasants...."
column3: There is now only one master of the Russian land: the union of the workers, soldiers and peasants...."

column2: With biting sarcasm he went on to speak of the Allied diplomats, till then contemptuous of Russia's invitation to an armistice, which had been accepted by the Central Powers.
column3: With biting sarcasm he went on to speak of the Allied diplomats, till then contemptuous of Russia's invitation to an armistice, which had been accepted by the Central Powers.

column2: A new humanity will be born of this war....	A new humanity will be born of this war....
column3: false

column2: In this hall we swear to workers of all lands to remain at our revolutionary post.
column3: In this hall we swear to workers of all lands to remain at our revolutionary post.

column2: If we are broken, then it will be in defending our flag...."
column3: If we are broken, then it will be in defending our flag...."

column2: Krylenko followed him, explaining the situation at the front, where Dukhonin was preparing to resist the Council of People's Commissars. "Let Dukhonin and those with him understand well that we shall not deal gently with those who bar the road to peace!"
column3: Krylenko followed him, explaining the situation at the front, where Dukhonin was preparing to resist the Council of People's Commissars. "Let Dukhonin and those with him understand well that we shall not deal gently with those who bar the road to peace!"

column2: Dybenko saluted the assembly in the name of the Fleet, and Krushinsky, member of the _Vikzhel,_ said, "From this moment, when the union of all true Socialists is realised, the whole army of railway workers places itself absolutely at the disposition of the revolutionary democracy!" And Lunatcharsky, almost weeping, and Proshian, for the Left Socialist Revolutionaries, and finally Saharashvili, for the United Social Democrats Internationalists, composed of members of the Martov's and of Gorky's groups, who declared:
column3: Dybenko saluted the assembly in the name of the Fleet, and Krushinsky, member of the underscore Vikzhel,underscore said, "From this moment, when the union of all true Socialists is realised, the whole army of railway workers places itself absolutely at the disposition of the revolutionary democracy!" And Lunatcharsky, almost weeping, and Proshian, for the Left Socialist Revolutionaries, and finally Saharashvili, for the United Social Democrats Internationalists, composed of members of the Martov's and of Gorky's groups, who declared:

column2: We left the _Tsay-ee-kah_ because of the uncompromising policy of the Bolsheviki, and to force them to make concessions in order to realise the union of all the revolutionary democracy.	We left the underscore Tsay ee kah underscore because of the uncompromising policy of the Bolsheviki, and to force them to make concessions in order to realise the union of all the revolutionary democracy.
column3: false

column2: Now that that union is brought about, we consider it a sacred duty to take our places once more in the _Tsay-ee-kah_....
column3: Now that that union is brought about, we consider it a sacred duty to take our places once more in the underscore Tsay ee kah underscore....

column2: We declare that all those who have withdrawn from the _Tsay-ee-kah_ should now return."
column3: We declare that all those who have withdrawn from the underscore Tsay ee kah underscore should now return."

column2: Stachkov, a dignified old peasant of the presidium of the Peasants' Congress, bowed to the four corners of the room.
column3: Stachkov, a dignified old peasant of the presidium of the Peasants' Congress, bowed to the four corners of the room.

column2: I greet you with the christening of a new Russian life and freedom!
column3: I greet you with the christening of a new Russian life and freedom!

column2: Gronsky, in the name of the Polish Social Democracy; Skripnik, for the Factory-Shop Committees; Tifonov, for the Russian soldiers at Salonika; and others, interminably, speaking out of full hearts, with the happy eloquence of hopes fulfilled....
column3: Gronsky, in the name of the Polish Social Democracy; Skripnik, for the Factory Shop Committees; Tifonov, for the Russian soldiers at Salonika; and others, interminably, speaking out of full hearts, with the happy eloquence of hopes fulfilled....

column2: It was late in the night when the following resolution was put and passed unanimously:
column3: It was late in the night when the following resolution was put and passed unanimously:

column2: The _Tsay-ee-kah,_ united in extraordinary session with the Petrograd Soviet and the Peasants' Congress, confirms the Land and Peace decrees adopted by the second Congress of Soviets of Workers' and Soldiers' Deputies, and also the decree on Workers' Control adopted by the _Tsay-ee-kah._	The underscore Tsay ee kah,underscore united in extraordinary session with the Petrograd Soviet and the Peasants' Congress, confirms the Land and Peace decrees adopted by the second Congress of Soviets of Workers' and Soldiers' Deputies, and also the decree on Workers' Control adopted by the underscore Tsay ee kah.underscore
column3: false

column2: The joint session of the _Tsay-ee-kah_ and the Peasants' Congress expresses its firm conviction that the union of workers, soldiers and peasants, this fraternal union of all the workers and all exploited, will consolidate the power conquered by them, that it will take all revolutionary measures to hasten the passing of the power into the hands of the working-class in other countries, and that it will assure in this manner the lasting accomplishment of a just peace and the victory of Socialism. (See App.
column3: The joint session of the underscore Tsay ee kah underscore and the Peasants' Congress expresses its firm conviction that the union of workers, soldiers and peasants, this fraternal union of all the workers and all exploited, will consolidate the power conquered by them, that it will take all revolutionary measures to hasten the passing of the power into the hands of the working class in other countries, and that it will assure in this manner the lasting accomplishment of a just peace and the victory of Socialism. (See App.
